md_sleep_tips_desc_1:
When we go a number of days without
getting enough sleep, we accumulate
“sleep debt.” Having sleep debt makes
us less able to function when we’re
awake, and what’s more, it poses
various risks to our health.
md_sleep_tips_desc_2:
Sleeping extra doesn't prevent sleep
debt. It's best not to think of sleep like
money in a bank—we can't store up
sleep to withdraw later.
md_sleep_tips_title_3: What's the Best Amount of Sleep?
md_sleep_tips_desc_3:
The best amount of sleep for you is
however much it takes to not feel tired
during the day. Try to sleep the same
amount every day—even on days off.
md_sleep_tips_desc_5:
There are a very small number of people
in the world who are known to be
naturally "short sleepers"—that is,
they can go without sleeping very much
and still be healthy.
md_sleep_tips_title_6: We Can't Reduce Our Sleep Needs
md_sleep_tips_desc_6:
We’re either born as short sleepers or
we aren’t. At present, it’s just about
impossible for us to deliberately turn
ourselves into short sleepers.
md_sleep_tips_title_7: What to Do When Short on Sleep
md_sleep_tips_desc_7:
When we're short on sleep, getting
enough sleep should be our top priority.
It's recommended to save work and
studies for later and focus on getting
deep sleep.
md_sleep_tips_title_8: When Should I Go to Bed?
md_sleep_tips_desc_8:
Ideally, we should go to bed at an hour
when we can fall asleep easily, rather
than going out of our way to match
someone else’s schedule.
md_sleep_tips_desc_9:
People are born as early risers or night
owls. It's said to be extremely hard
for night people to deliberately become
morning people.
md_sleep_tips_desc_10:
It's best to eat dinner three to four
hours before bed at the latest.
Digesting our food thoroughly before
sleep is important.
md_sleep_tips_desc_11:
When our core body temperature
drops, we get sleepy. Eating makes our
internal organs start working, and that
raises our core body temperature,
making it harder to fall asleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_12:
We each run on our own biological
clock, and its cycle isn’t exactly 24
hours. Having breakfast after we wake
up resets our biological clock, so we
can ideally sync up with the 24-hour
day cycle.
md_sleep_tips_desc_13:
If on weekends, we sleep for very long
times—especially at later hours than on
other days—we get "social jet lag." Not
only is this detrimental to our health,
it can also negatively impact how well
we function when Monday comes.
md_sleep_tips_desc_14:
It's said that one of sleep's functions is
to let our brains recover from fatigue.
We need sleep to give our brains regular
upkeep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_15:
Having a high core body temperature
makes it hard to sleep well. Taking a
hot bath raises our core temperature,
so a bath right before bed can make
falling asleep a challenge.
md_sleep_tips_desc_16:
It's recommended to finish up activities
that raise core body temperature—such
as bathing and exercise—at least an
hour before bed.
md_sleep_tips_desc_17:
When we fall asleep, we start out
dozing, then move back and forth
between lighter and deeper sleep.
Repetitions of these stages form
what’s known as sleep cycles.
md_sleep_tips_desc_18:
In one night’s sleep, we go through
roughly four to six sleep cycles.
md_sleep_tips_desc_19:
A single sleep cycle generally lasts
around 90 minutes. But their lengths
can vary from day to day, or even
within the same night’s sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_20:
Slumbering is a deep-sleep stage that’s
said to be crucial for reinforcing and
strengthening memory.
md_sleep_tips_desc_21:
In the snoozing stage of sleep, our
brains may be in a state similar to
being awake, even though our bodies
are asleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_22:
It was recently discovered that some
parts of our brains are more active
in the snoozing stage than they are
when we're awake!
md_sleep_tips_desc_23:
In order to get to sleep, we need to be
sleepy enough—but what exactly is
sleepiness? How does it work? No one
has a clear answer yet. Research into
the question is ongoing.
md_sleep_tips_desc_24:
Getting to sleep can be hard when
you're very hungry. It may be best to
avoid eating dinner too early as well as
too late.
md_sleep_tips_desc_25:
Caffeine affects the parts of our
brains that are responsible for making
us sleepy. It may be good to avoid
caffeine starting five to six hours
before you go to sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_26:
It's said that our body temperatures
start to cool around the time we fall
asleep, and are lowest while we're
sleeping. This change in temperature is
thought to be another important factor
in the quality of our sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_27:
Our biological clocks are what make
us wake up and start functioning when
the sun rises and get sleepy when
night falls.
md_sleep_tips_desc_28:
Light is essential for regulating our
biological clocks. The sight of sunlight
soon after we wake up is what lets our
bodies know it's morning.
md_sleep_tips_desc_29:
Our biological clocks are managed by a
“master clock” in our brains. Seeing
bright light at night throws off this
master clock and interferes with sleep.
It’s good to keep our rooms as dark as
possible when it’s time for bed.
md_sleep_tips_title_30: Is Staying Up All Night Bad for Us?
md_sleep_tips_desc_30:
It's known that the more sleep we
lose, the more prone we are to making
mistakes. In other words, pulling an
all-nighter to cram for a test can have
the opposite effect to what we intend.
md_sleep_tips_title_31: Do I Need Sleep to Grow?
md_sleep_tips_desc_31:
Along with its other benefits, the deep
sleep we get in the slumbering stage is
said to be very important to growing up
healthily.
md_sleep_tips_desc_32:
No one yet knows for sure why we
dream. But some have suggested that
it has to do with the way our brains
perform maintenance on themselves in
our sleep.
md_sleep_tips_title_33: How Long Kids Need to Sleep
md_sleep_tips_desc_33:
How long we need to sleep depends on
how old we are. Kids need to sleep for
longer than adults do.
md_sleep_tips_desc_34:
In our everyday lives, we tend to get
less sleep than we should. First and
foremost, you should try to prioritize
getting as much sleep as you need.
md_sleep_tips_title_35: Why We Roll Over in Our Sleep
md_sleep_tips_desc_35:
If we stay in the same position the
whole time we sleep, it can put strain
on our bodies. Rolling over helps
lighten that strain.
md_sleep_tips_desc_36:
When we sleep comfortably, we don't
roll over too often. If we sleep on
bedding that's too soft or too hard,
we roll over more often to reduce the
strain on our bodies.
md_sleep_tips_desc_37:
Snoring a lot is known to make our
sleep unstable. If you get the feeling
you haven't been sleeping well, it may
be worth looking into how much you've
been snoring.
md_sleep_tips_desc_38:
The changing of the seasons seems to
be a factor in how long we sleep. It's
said that we sleep less when days are
longer and more when days are short.
md_sleep_tips_desc_39:
Building up lots of sleep debt can be
dangerous—it may cause us to
experience microsleeps, or momentary
losses of consciousness. To prevent
this, it’s very important to sleep enough
and in a consistent way every day.
md_sleep_tips_desc_41:
If you repeatedly find yourself getting
sleepy and falling asleep easily during
the day, it's probably a sign that you've
built up lots of sleep debt. Please try
hard to get enough sleep.
md_sleep_tips_title_42: Do Dreams Come in Types, Too?
md_sleep_tips_desc_42:
What stage of sleep we're in is known
to affect what kinds of dreams we
have. For example, research shows
that our dreams tend to be more
clearly memorable when we're dozing.
md_sleep_tips_desc_43:
We're said to be more creative after a
good night's sleep than if we'd stayed
awake all night.
md_sleep_tips_desc_44:
How much sleep we get is said to be
linked to our bodies' natural defenses.
Some research suggests that getting
less sleep can make us more prone
to catching colds.
md_sleep_tips_desc_45:
Being in too-brightly-lit places before
bed can impact our sleep. Adjusting
the light in our surroundings may help
bring healthier sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_46:
If we don't get enough sleep, we may
develop more of a sweet tooth than
usual. This is said to be because lack of
sleep affects the part of our brains
that regulates food preferences.
md_sleep_tips_desc_47:
If you find yourself tired during the
day, taking a 15- to 20-minute nap
may help. But getting enough sleep at
night is best, so don’t forget to focus
on that.
md_sleep_tips_desc_48:
If you have trouble falling asleep,
it’s better not to go to bed when you
are not sleepy. It’s important to do
something relaxing and wait for
sleepiness to set in, rather than try
to force sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_49:
Some studies have shown that warming
up our feet can help us sleep better.
A foot bath before bed may be worth a
try.
md_sleep_tips_desc_50:
Eating breakfast within an hour after
waking up is important for regulating
our biological clocks. Even when we're
busy, skipping breakfast and waiting
until lunch isn't the best idea.
md_sleep_tips_desc_51:
Eating without chewing your food well
is said to throw off your sleep cycle.
That means in order to sleep well, you
need to chew well, too.
md_sleep_tips_desc_52:
Keeping your room as quiet as possible
is one important factor in getting
good sleep. It's said that sounds like
people talking can be especially
disruptive to sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_53:
When you're sleeping, try to maintain
the right temperature for you all the
way until morning. Being too hot or
too cold isn't good for your sleep.
md_sleep_tips_desc_54:
When going to sleep at night, it's best
to be in as complete darkness as
possible. If you feel unsafe, using a
night light or other dim light is OK.
